articles.headline: The Next Fear on A.I.: Hollywood’s Killer Robots Become the Military’s Tools
articles.snippet: U.S. national security officials are warning about the potential for the new technology to upend war, cyber conflict and — in the most extreme case — the use of nuclear weapons.
articles.abstract: U.S. national security officials are warning about the potential for the new technology to upend war, cyber conflict and — in the most extreme case — the use of nuclear weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Biden announced sharp restrictions in October on selling the most advanced computer chips to China, he sold it in part as a way of giving American industry a chance to restore its competitiveness.

articles.headline: Tucker Carlson Wants to Return to TV Before 2025. Will Fox Let Him?
articles.snippet: In conversations with his associates, Mr. Carlson has expressed interest in getting back to work before the agreement expires.
articles.abstract: In conversations with his associates, Mr. Carlson has expressed interest in getting back to work before the agreement expires.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tucker Carlson is making it clear to people close to him that he would like to be back on the air somewhere soon. But he first needs Fox News to agree to a deal that would allow him to work elsewhere, according to three people with knowledge of the discussions, leaving it unclear whether he will be able to start a new chapter in his media career before his current contract expires in January 2025.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: Tightening Supreme Court Ethics Rules Faces Steep Hurdles
articles.snippet: Revelations about Justice Clarence Thomas’s failure to disclose largess from a Republican donor have highlighted a dilemma.
articles.abstract: Revelations about Justice Clarence Thomas’s failure to disclose largess from a Republican donor have highlighted a dilemma.
articles.lead_paragraph: The drumbeat of revelations that Justice Clarence Thomas did not disclose lavish gifts and significant financial arrangements with a billionaire Republican donor has put a spotlight on the fact that the Supreme Court has the weakest ethics rules in the federal government.

articles.headline: Backup Power: A Growing Need, if You Can Afford It
articles.snippet: Extreme weather linked to climate change is causing more blackouts. But generators and batteries are still out of reach for many.
articles.abstract: Extreme weather linked to climate change is causing more blackouts. But generators and batteries are still out of reach for many.
articles.lead_paragraph: When frigid weather caused rolling blackouts on Christmas Eve across North Carolina, Eliana and David Mundula quickly grew worried about their 2½-week-old daughter, whom they had brought home days earlier from a neonatal intensive care unit.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Hearing Aids Are Changing. Their Users Are, Too.
articles.snippet: As more young people risk hearing loss, over-the-counter hearing aids are providing new options, but also confusing choices.
articles.abstract: As more young people risk hearing loss, over-the-counter hearing aids are providing new options, but also confusing choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ayla Wing’s middle school students don’t always know what to make of their 26-year-old teacher’s hearing aids. The most common response she hears: “Oh, my grandma has them, too.”

articles.headline: War, Weapons and Conspiracy Theories: Inside Airman Teixeira’s Online World
articles.snippet: A review of more than 9,500 messages obtained by The New York Times offers important clues about the mind-set of a young airman implicated in a vast leak of government secrets.
articles.abstract: A review of more than 9,500 messages obtained by The New York Times offers important clues about the mind-set of a young airman implicated in a vast leak of government secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jack Teixeira, the Air National Guardsman implicated in a vast leak of classified documents, was fixated on weapons, mass shootings, shadowy conspiracy theories — and proving he was in the right, and in the know.
articles.byline: By Aric Toler, Robin Stein, Glenn Thrush, Riley Mellen and Ishaan Jhaveri

articles.headline: Charles Is Crowned King in Ancient Ceremony With Modern Twists
articles.snippet: The coronation, the first since Queen Elizabeth II’s in 1953, was a royal spectacle of the kind that only Britain still stages.
articles.abstract: The coronation, the first since Queen Elizabeth II’s in 1953, was a royal spectacle of the kind that only Britain still stages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anointed with holy oil and enthroned on St. Edward’s chair, King Charles III was crowned on Saturday in a solemn ritual that stretches back more than a millennium but unfolded with multiple concessions to the modern age.

articles.headline: The Unexpected Women Blocking South Carolina’s Near-Total Abortion Ban
articles.snippet: They call themselves the “Sister Senators” and three of them are Republicans.
articles.abstract: They call themselves the “Sister Senators” and three of them are Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the United States Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last summer, advocates on either side presumed that the country would divide along the bright color lines: red states completely banning abortion, blue states protecting it.

articles.headline: An End to Pandemic Restrictions Could Bring Thousands to the Border
articles.snippet: Title 42, the policy that has allowed the swift expulsion of many migrants at the southern border, will lift on Thursday. Officials are bracing for a new immigration surge.
articles.abstract: Title 42, the policy that has allowed the swift expulsion of many migrants at the southern border, will lift on Thursday. Officials are bracing for a new immigration surge.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — The Biden administration is preparing to lift an emergency health rule that has been used to prevent hundreds of thousands of migrants from entering the United States, setting the stage for what could be a new immigration surge that inflames political tensions and strains resources across the southern border.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Mortgage Fees (Seriously) Spurred Outrage on TikTok. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: Changes to fees applied to federal mortgages have led to a misconception that borrowers with low credit scores will pay less at the expense of borrowers with good credit.
articles.abstract: Changes to fees applied to federal mortgages have led to a misconception that borrowers with low credit scores will pay less at the expense of borrowers with good credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mortgage fees usually induce yawns and glazed-over eyes. But when word began circulating last month that updated pricing would cost some home buyers more, it resulted in viral TikTok videos with thousands of outraged comments misinterpreting the new rules.

articles.headline: Liz Holmes Wants You to Forget About Elizabeth
articles.snippet: The black turtlenecks are gone. So is the voice. As the convicted Theranos founder awaits prison, she has adopted a new persona: devoted mother.
articles.abstract: The black turtlenecks are gone. So is the voice. As the convicted Theranos founder awaits prison, she has adopted a new persona: devoted mother.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Holmes blends in with the other moms here, in a bucket hat and sunglasses, her newborn strapped to her chest and swathed in a Baby Yoda nursing blanket. We walk past a family of caged orangutans and talk about how Ms. Holmes is preparing to go to prison for one of the most notorious cases of corporate fraud in recent history.

articles.headline: Ukrainians Return Home, Renewed and Resigned
articles.snippet: More than 5.5 million people who left after the war began in February 2022 have gone back home — and not just to large cities like Kyiv or Dnipro, but to small places near the front line, as well.
articles.abstract: More than 5.5 million people who left after the war began in February 2022 have gone back home — and not just to large cities like Kyiv or Dnipro, but to small places near the front line, as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new sound wafts through the open windows at night in this town near the front line: children hollering at each other down the block, even long after dark.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O'Reilly

articles.headline: Twitter Criticized for Allowing Texas Shooting Images to Spread
articles.snippet: Graphic images of the attack went viral on the platform, which has made cuts to its moderation team. Some users said the images exposed the realities of gun violence.
articles.abstract: Graphic images of the attack went viral on the platform, which has made cuts to its moderation team. Some users said the images exposed the realities of gun violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pat Holloway has seen her share of destruction during a 30-year career as a photojournalist: the 1993 standoff in Waco, Texas; the 1995 bombing of a federal building in Oklahoma City by Timothy McVeigh; and the 2011 tornado that struck Joplin, Mo.

articles.headline: After Mass Killings in Texas, Frustration but No Action on Guns
articles.snippet: The drumbeat of mass murder has fueled a new openness to gun regulation among some Texans, but it has done little to reshape the political realities in the State Capitol.
articles.abstract: The drumbeat of mass murder has fueled a new openness to gun regulation among some Texans, but it has done little to reshape the political realities in the State Capitol.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — After months of pleading for more gun control measures, a Democrat who represents Uvalde, Texas, where 19 children died in a mass shooting, was told by the Republican leader of the State Senate to stop bringing up gun legislation or be barred from speaking at all.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman, Adam Goldman, Edgar Sandoval and David Montgomery

articles.headline: ‘It’s Going to Be a While’: No End in Sight for Hollywood Strike
articles.snippet: The writers and entertainment companies remain far apart on several key issues, including money, and the standoff could last for months.
articles.abstract: The writers and entertainment companies remain far apart on several key issues, including money, and the standoff could last for months.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not just posturing: As screenwriters continue their strike against Hollywood companies, the two sides remain a galaxy apart, portending a potentially long and destructive standoff.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin

articles.headline: A Philosopher and a Slaver, but No Longer a Name on a Library
articles.snippet: No one disputes that George Berkeley was among Ireland’s greatest thinkers, but he was also an unapologetic slaver. Now, Trinity College Dublin is taking his name off one of its buildings.
articles.abstract: No one disputes that George Berkeley was among Ireland’s greatest thinkers, but he was also an unapologetic slaver. Now, Trinity College Dublin is taking his name off one of its buildings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trinity College Dublin has decided to seek a new name for its central library, the Berkeley, after concluding that the alumnus it honors, the 18th-century philosopher George Berkeley, owned slaves in colonial Rhode Island and wrote pamphlets supportive of slavery.

articles.headline: In Norway, the Electric Vehicle Future Has Already Arrived
articles.snippet: About 80 percent of new cars sold in Norway are battery-powered. As a result, the air is cleaner, the streets are quieter and the grid hasn’t collapsed. But problems with unreliable chargers persist.
articles.abstract: About 80 percent of new cars sold in Norway are battery-powered. As a result, the air is cleaner, the streets are quieter and the grid hasn’t collapsed. But problems with unreliable chargers persist.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMBLE, Norway — About 110 miles south of Oslo, along a highway lined with pine and birch trees, a shiny fueling station offers a glimpse of a future where electric vehicles rule.
